comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT of April 27, 1915 reports that Mrs. Alma V Hayne was married to Donald Shields Andrews the previous Saturday. The article also mentions that she had a six-year-old son. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9801EEDE1338E633A... NYT of June 15, 1915 reports that Mr. Andrews (a senior at Yale, who had married against his parents will) returned alone from England, where his wife remained. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=940DE2D81539E333A...

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: fultonhistory.com/Process%20small/Newspapers/Oswego%20Pal... indicates that she committed suicide in 1919, with plenty of mystery surrounding her. The Singapore Free Press and Mercantile Advertiser (1884-1942), 18 July 1930, Page 3 A LONDON MYSTERY RECALLED. newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/singfreepressb19300718... Reports the death of Donald Shields Andrews and provides more details about her, including the name of her third husband, Captain Cedric Sebastian Steane.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT of Jan 16, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20C1EFB3E5F17738... reveals that the son is Rudolph Hayne, known as Bunny.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Alma and Rudolph arrived in the U.S. (one time among many, according to the newspaper stories) on the Arcadian on February 6, 1913, from Bermuda.  At the time she was 23 and Rudolph 4.

comment._content: I started an entry in Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alma_V._Hayne

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: swanq and Richard Arthur Norton:  Thank you for the additional details about Alma Hayne and her son.  We will add more information to the description when we update.

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Full-size version now on Wikimedia Commons: commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Alma_V_Hayne_(Mrs_Donald_...

comment.author: 10799299@N00
comment._content: There is a "tell all" article published in 1921 in the Pittsburgh Press news.google.com/newspapers?id=Vh8bAAAAIBAJ&sjid=u0kEA... by Bernard Francis Seraph Gregory, a con man who called himself "Count Gregory" in which he claims he discovered Alma in Toronto, where she was the wife of a British Army Captain, and coached her on her princess act. Now how much you can believe anything in a confession by a self described swindler published in a sensational newspaper is a good question. It would be interesting to know her real background and what happened to her poor son.

comment.author: 10799299@N00
comment._content: Here is the next part of the Pittsburgh Press article news.google.com/newspapers?id=XR8bAAAAIBAJ&sjid=u0kEA... and the last part news.google.com/newspapers?id=2gIbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vEkEA...

comment.author: 18299996@N03
comment._content: Thanks for the photo. Alma was the grandmother of my stepfather and i have been fascinated by her life, it was indeed dramatic. No one has been able to ascertain her true beginnings. She first shows up in 1907 in her first marriage, with the Name Alma Irene Zetkous, claiming Austrian birth and deceased parents in Toronto, Ontario.

comment.author: 18299996@N03
comment._content: Just to add, the poor son was taken under the wing of a Baron in England and sent to Sandhurst Academy.  He flew a trans-African flight during the 1930's and he was given a commision and was stationed in Southern Africa during WWII, well away from action in North Africa and claims the only thing he shot was a pod of whales, mistaking them for U-Boats.  He then married and emigrated to Canada after the war having a small farm in BC and three sons.

comment.author: 10799299@N00
comment._content: Oh excellent, I'm glad to hear things turned out ok for her son. He looks kind of sad in that photo.

comment.author: 62159353@N03
comment._content: I personally find this picture as well as the links provided quite interesting, as I'm the great grandchild of C. Rudolph Hayne, my grandfather being his second son. I'm more than positive that my family doesn't know any more about Alma than what has been said, but it's quite interesting to find her stories and bits of her life in the newspaper.
